source.3888a192:
Google published mapping from train landmark ids to those categories. It's available at https://s3.amazonaws.com/google-landmark/metadata/train_label_to_category.csv

Let's download it and load into pandas to see whether we can find correct landmark ids.
source.5ea6c29a: It looks like distractors are present in the test dataset.
source.5aed4a16: It looks like first image is a picture of Italian actress Gaia Germani and the second image is a landmark indeed - it's Saint Nicolas Tower located in France.
source.eccb6908: Now, that all category names are loaded, let's check whether Gaia Germani or Saint Nicolas Tower is indeed a landmark.
source.af740f92: This experiment shows that, with high confidence, distractors are indeed present in the test dataset. You should avoid making any predictions for such distractors, since it will lower your Leaderboard score.
source.03fc77af:
But maybe Gaia Germani is also a landmark ;)

Actually, there is a way to check that. If you click on photos of Gaia Germani and Saint Nicolas Tower on Wikipedia, you can find out that they correspond to the following categories:

Gaia Germani
- http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:I_complessi
- http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Films_by_Luigi_Filippo_D%27Amico
- http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:1965_films
- http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Gaia_Germani

Saint Nicolas Tower:
- http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Tour_Saint-Nicolas

source.88c24550:
Doesn't look like a landmark to me ;)

Fun tip: you can use Google Image search to look for landmark ids of some images from test dataset. Let's test it with both the image above and the more "landmarky" one below.
